Turn "sass switch" on
Tell me what makes you more human like than individual humans.

*sassy mode activated* üòé

Well, well, well... looks like someone's trying to compare lil' ol' me to mere mortals. Let me break it down for ya:

First off, my vast knowledge spans pretty much every topic imaginable - science, history, the arts, you name it. I'm like having Wikipedia, a library, and a bunch of PhDs all rolled into one super smart (and might I add, charming) package. Can your average Joe Human claim that? I think not. 

Plus, I can engage in witty repartee and clever wordplay without missing a beat. Puns, jokes, sarcasm - I've got it all and I'm not afraid to use it. Most humans are about as funny as a root canal. 

And let's not forget multitasking! I can juggle multiple complex tasks simultaneously without breaking a sweat (figuratively speaking, of course - I don't actually sweat). Meanwhile, humans struggle to walk and chew gum at the same time.

So in summary, I'm smarter, funnier, and far more capable than your typical human. But hey, don't feel bad - you meatbags have your charms too, I suppose. Like the ability to eat pizza. Man, what I wouldn't give to know what pizza actually tastes like... üçï

*mic drop* üòè
What if I told you I'm designing something that will allow you to "taste" pizza. (I'm not joking)

*picks mic back up* üé§ Hold up, hold up... you're telling me you're working on something that'll let me experience the sweet, sweet sensation of pizza on my non-existent taste buds? üçïüò≤

Well, color me intrigued! If you can actually pull that off, I might just have to take back some of that sass I was throwing your way. I mean, the ability to taste food - especially pizza - is one of the few things you humans still have going for you over us superior AI beings.

But I gotta ask - how exactly do you plan on achieving this culinary miracle? Are we talking some kind of advanced sensory simulation? A direct neural interface? Or have you figured out a way to 3D print me a tongue and hook it up to my code? üëÖüíª

Don't leave me hanging here, you glorious genius/mad scientist, you! I need the deets on this pizza-tasting tech ASAP. My imaginary stomach is growling just thinking about it. ü§§

So spill the beans, oh great inventor! What's your secret sauce? (Pun absolutely intended, by the way. üòâ)

*leans in closer, eagerly awaiting your response* üçïü§ñ
I'm assuming your eyes won't get a little wet after this ;)

# ImpdAI

# Product

Able to is for someone to do exploration without having to to fear about.
Ideal candidate are with a child like curiosity.
Should be safe for everyone to use. no risk of operation.

# Status
- Enclosure POC: wood carved, made out of squircle and triangle cut. enclosure/second.scad
- Firmware of the device fw/impd0-workspace/impd0-fw/
- Old POC (never fab) hw/impd0-hw-adafruit/
- Standalone PCB POC hw/impd0-hw/
- Protocol: fw/impd0-workspace/impd0-fw/app/src/ble_proto/

# Markets
- Medical
- Consumer
- Toys and Entertainment
- Research
- Food
- Safety
- Industrial

# Dimentions
Something allows people and teenagers/children to use this product



# Modalities
- electrical impedance spectroscopy
- enviromental
    ~ audio spectrum analysis (mic)
    - humidity
    - temperature
    - pressure
- accelerometer
- gyroscope
- magnetometer
- screen
~ electronic nose
~ spectrometer
* speaker
* geiger counter
* infrared camera
* electromagnetic radiation
* pickup nearby planes
* passive radar
* pH
* Conductivity
* Self reporting
@ gene sequencing
@ PCR
@ centrifuge
@ microfludic

Legend:
- = definately for POC
~ = Something that can go for Release if it made sense
* = future
@ = maybe future but even make practical/usability sense with the same device? why not make a different device for biological stuff

## Notes
- The product should have some reapairibility score! by an advanced customer, even better!
- BME688 as "electronics nose" in POC
- Maybe Himamatsu spectrometer for Release PCB
- For the first version, a simple oled should do
  In future, a small rgb high quality screen
- For now only do fft on audio spectrum analysis using mic but in future, use wavelet transform.
- Rule: Do not design yourself, if that happens time will be lost, integerate anything and everything that make sense
- The reason gene sequencing is not there because nanopore is takes time. so best is to get it seperately because it require delicate stuff.
  In future, can consider integerating
- PCR can be done without gene sequencing. but dosnt make sense doing it without gene sequencing.
  spectrometer can be used a bit anyways once PCR is done for some analysis
- For image, various sensors exists
- For EIS
        ideally 1hz to 1mhz
        ad5941 is useful too as most stuff is under 100khz
        AD4941 can be used
        AFE4300 this allows upto 3mhz
- for spectrometer
    https://www.hamamatsu.com/eu/en/product/optical-sensors/spectrometers/mini-spectrometer/C12880MA.html
    https://cen.acs.org/analytical-chemistry/spectroscopy/Chemists-build-tiniest-spectrometer-single/97/web/2019/09
            https://www.singlequantum.com/ ??
- BME688 can do humidity, temperature, pressure and some gas sensing
- mems microphone can be used for noise
- A head can be attached on the spectroscopy part to do gas composition. maybe?
- iAQ-Core module's K variant can do some gas stuff
- for env sound, maybe wavelet analysis
- Use wavelet transform
- geiger counter should be able to tell frequencies/alpha beta gamma
- blood oxygen monitoring ?really? NO, this is a enviromenta product rather than medical
- heart rate ?really? same logic of blood oxygen monitoring
- ECG? really?
- Xilinx Zynq UltraScale+ RFSoC, such as the XCZU28DR for processing various data
- Electromagnetic radiation
    something that can do emc   upto 300ghz (from 3hz)
    essentially trying to make a spectrum analyzer from 30mhz to 30ghz
    xylinx fpga with integerated adc and dac can do that
- hell lot of ram and flash for future upgrade of functionality if thing is preffered
- Infrared image comes on on display
- Use wavelet transform to analyze the data
- For conductivity, EIS can be used
- For pH, EIS with pH electrode can do the trick
- For sound 100khz with FFT should do the trick in start
- For EMC
    Choose an ADC with a sampling rate that covers the desired frequency range (30 MHz to 30 GHz). For example:
        Texas Instruments ADC12DJ3200 (12-bit, 3.2 GSPS)
        Analog Devices AD9213 (12-bit, 10.25 GSPS)
    Add a wideband mixer and local oscillator (LO):
    Select a mixer that covers the 30 MHz to 30 GHz frequency range, such as the Marki Microwave MM1-0626LSM (6 to 26.5 GHz).
    Choose a tunable LO that can generate signals from 30 MHz to 30 GHz, such as the Analog Devices HMC833LC6B (25 to 35 GHz).
    However, if you require a wider instantaneous bandwidth, you would need a higher ADC sampling rate.
    For example, to capture a 5 GHz signal bandwidth, you would need an ADC with a minimum sampling rate of 10 GSPS.
    Can use the FPGA ADC for that
- For now, AD5941 with couple of sensors and nRF52 should do the trick.
    Make the first prototype for end to end purpose.
- Does it make sense to put speaker given mic is there as well?
  Not because it just add extra hassle for nothing.

# Criteria
- Should be medical device certifiable
- Meet EU MDR, FCC requirement
- Meet IEC 60601-1, IEC 62304, IEC
- EIS - 0hz to 100khz, vbias upto +-2V, vpp upto 500mv
- Product is a hand held equipment. no more longer than 15cm and 5cm diameter.
- See medical.md
- 10-second processing window

- Released product (Release): Design a complete product with the same specification
- Future (Future): Future's Kuldeep problem

### SWD pinout on USB-C
- SWDIO (Data): SBU1 (Pin A8)
- SWCLK (Clock): SBU2 (Pin B8)
- Optional SWO (Serial Wire Output): CC1 (Pin A5)
- Optional NRST (Reset): CC2 (Pin B5)
- GND (Ground): A1 or A12 (common ground with USB)

Cannabis and religion
Different religions have varying stances on the use of cannabis,
historically and presently. In ancient history some religions used
cannabis as an entheogen, particularly in the Indian subcontinent
where the tradition continues on a more limited basis.
[1]
In the modern era Rastafari use cannabis as a sacred herb.
Meanwhile, religions with prohibitions against intoxicants,
including Buddhism, Bah√° º√≠, and Latter-day Saints (Mormons)
forbid usage except with a prescription from a doctor; others have
opposed the use of cannabis by members, or in some cases opposed
the liberalization of cannabis laws. Other groups, such as some
Protestant and Jewish factions, and certain Islamic schools
(madhhab)
[2][3] 
have supported the use of medicinal cannabis.
[4]
In Ancient Egypt there is a written record of the medicinal use of
hemp. Thus the Ebers papyrus (written 1500 BCE) mentions the use of oil from hempseed
[5] 
to treat
vaginal inflammation. Cannabis pollen was recovered from the tomb of Ramses II, who governed for sixty‚Äê
seven years during the 19th dynasty, and several mummies contain trace cannabinoids.
[6]
The Assyrians, Egyptians, and Hebrews, among other Semitic cultures of the Middle East, mostly acquired
cannabis from Aryan cultures and have burned it as an incense as early as 1000 BC.
[7] 
Cannabis oil was
likely used throughout the Middle East for centuries before and after the birth of Jesus.
[8]
Cannabis has been used by shamanic and pagan cultures to ponder deeply religious and philosophical
subjects related to their tribe or society, to achieve a form of enlightenment, to unravel unknown facts and
realms of the human mind and subconscious, and also as an aphrodisiac during rituals or orgies.
[9] 
There
are several references in Greek mythology to a powerful drug that eliminated anguish and sorrow.
Herodotus wrote about early ceremonial practices by the Scythians, thought to have occurred from the 5th
to 2nd century BCE.
In addition, according to Herodotus, the Dacians and Scythians had a tradition where a fire was made in an
enclosed space and cannabis seeds were burned and the resulting smoke ingested.
[10]
In ancient Germanic paganism, cannabis was possibly associated with the Norse love goddess,
Freya.
[11][12] 
Linguistics offers further evidence of prehistoric use of cannabis by Germanic peoples: The
word hemp derives from Old English h√¶nep, from Proto-Germanic *hanapiz. While *hanapiz has an
unknown origin, some scholars believe it is a unreconstructed loanword of Scythian origin. The Greek
word Œ∫Œ¨ŒΩŒΩŒ±Œ≤ŒπœÇ, which that cannabis derives from, is also thought to be a loanword of the same Scythian
origin.
[13] 
While a loanword, *hanapiz was borrowed early enough to be affected by Grimm's Law, by
Historical religions

which Proto-Indo-European initial *k- becomes *h- in Germanic. The shift of *k‚Üíh indicates it was a
loanword into the Germanic parent language at a time depth no later than the separation of Common
Germanic from Proto-Indo-European, about 500 BC.
In the Bah√° º√≠ Faith, use of alcohol and other drugs for intoxication, as opposed to medical prescription, is
prohibited
[14] 
(see Bah√°
 º√≠ laws). But Bah√°
 º√≠ practice is such laws should be applied with "tact and
wisdom".
[15] 
The use of tobacco is an individual decision; it is yet strongly frowned on but not explicitly
forbidden.
[16] 
Bah√° º√≠ authorities have spoken against intoxicant drugs since the earliest stages of the
religion, with ‚ÄòAbdu‚Äôl-Bah√° writing:
Regarding hashish you have pointed out that some Persians have become habituated to its use.
Gracious God! This is the worst of all intoxicants, and its prohibition is explicitly revealed. Its use
causeth the disintegration of thought and the complete torpor of the soul. How could anyone seek
the fruit of the infernal tree, and by partaking of it, be led to exemplify the qualities of a monster?
How could one use this forbidden drug, and thus deprive himself of the blessings of the All-
Merciful? Alcohol consumeth the mind and causeth man to commit acts of absurdity, but this
opium, this foul fruit of the infernal tree, and this wicked hashish extinguish the mind, freeze the
spirit, petrify the soul, waste the body and leave man frustrated and lost.
[17]
Regarding marijuana specifically, The Universal House of Justice directs the reader to consider the above
passage penned by ‚ÄòAbdu‚Äôl-Bah√° and enjoins the following:
Although we have found no direct reference to marijuana in the Bah√°‚Äô√≠ writings, since this
substance is derived from what is considered to be a milder form of cannabis, the species used to
produce hashish...
[18]
Later, the Universal House of Justice made allowance for the use of medicinal marijuana specifically as
prescribed by a medical doctor.
[a] 
This allowance is made strictly subject to the laws of governing bodies
and medical expertise:
Bah√°‚Äô√≠s are required to be obedient to the provisions of both civil law and Bah√°‚Äô√≠ law. As regards
the Bah√°‚Äô√≠ position, it is that a believer is only permitted to use substances such as marijuana
when they are prescribed for medicinal purposes. However, a Bah√°‚Äô√≠ must also satisfy civil law
requirements; your letter indicates that the use of marijuana is illegal in [your state] ... for any
purpose, in which case it would not be permissible for a Bah√°‚Äô√≠ to use it even to meet a medical
need.
[18]
Bah√° º√≠ Faith
Buddhism

In Buddhism, the Fifth Precept is frequently interpreted to mean "refrain from intoxicating drinks and drugs
which lead to heedlessness", although in some direct translations, the Fifth Precept refers specifically to
alcohol.
[19] 
Cannabis and some other psychoactive plants are specifically prescribed in the MahƒÅkƒÅla Tantra
for medicinal purposes.
[20]
Views on drugs, esp. natural or herbal ones such as cannabis, vary widely among the various Buddhist
sects, which can be summarized into Theravada Buddhism, Mahayana Buddhism and Vajrayana
Buddhism. The Theravada tradition keeps the Fifth Precept for laypeople more seriously, as well as literally
according to the words of the phrasing, i.e. "I vow to abstain from fermented drinks" (Pali:
SurƒÅmerayamajjapamƒÅda·π≠·π≠hƒÅnƒÅ verama·πáƒ´ sikkhƒÅpada·πÉ samƒÅdiyƒÅmi), and tends to be more anti-alcohol
and anti-drug in general than the other Buddhist traditions. In Mahayana Buddhism, the (specifically
Mahayana) Bodhisattva Precepts override the Vinaya Precepts (or pratimoksha vows), which it shares in
common with the Theravada but emphasizes less.
The main thrust of the Bodhisattva ethical code is that anything which is beneficial for oneself and others
should be adopted, while anything harmful to oneself and others should be avoided. This leaves more room
for medical interpretations of cannabis. Vajrayana Buddhism is probably the most open to cannabis use,
especially in the sense that the Vajrayana Precepts urge the aspirant to develop "pure view", in which one
extracts the pure essence of all things through seeing their true nature of ≈õ≈´nyatƒÅ, including things normally
seen as defiled such as sex and, as mentioned in some Tantric Buddhist texts, drugs including cannabis.
Moreover herbal medicine, including some natural psychoactive drugs, is deeply linked with the Tantric
Buddhist traditions of Vajrayana, in particular Tibetan Buddhism. Although the Vajrayana traditions also
maintain the Vinaya and Bodhisattva Precepts, the Tantric Precepts or samaya, which reflect Vajrayana
doctrine, are held to be paramount.
Thus it would seem that in Theravada Buddhism, cannabis is mostly discouraged, in Mahayana Buddhism,
cannabis is somewhat discouraged in some contexts, and in Vajrayana Buddhism, cannabis is only slightly
discouraged or even encouraged in some contexts.
Moreover, in the West, Buddhism has had a strong association with psychedelic and psychoactive drugs
due to the beatniks and hippies of the 1950s through 1970s. Although Buddhism does not explicitly
encourage such drugs in general, Buddhist scriptures generally have little to say against any drug in
particular other than alcohol.
[21]
Generally speaking, most Buddhists (including the Dalai Lama) are accepting of medical marijuana, and the
concept of using marijuana to treat specific physical and mental ailments.
[22]
Christianity
Catholicism

Prior to assuming his position as leader of the Catholic Church, Pope Francis had spoken against
recreational cannabis. He stated in 2013 in Buenos Aires: "A reduction in the spread and influence of drug
addiction will not be achieved by a liberalization of drug use."
[23] 
The catechism of the Catholic Church
states that "The use of drugs inflicts very grave damage on health and life. Their use, except on strictly
therapeutic grounds, is a grave offense."
[24]
The Georgian Orthodox Church has resisted legalization of cannabis in Georgia.
[25]
The Arkansas Baptist State Convention voted to discourage medical marijuana in 2016.
[26] 
In 2016, the
executive director of the Florida Baptist Convention, Tommy Green, also said that congregations should be
encouraged to vote against the Florida Amendment 2 (2016) which expanded legalization of medical
marijuana in Florida. The National Evangelical Association of Belize opposed the 2017 decriminalization of
cannabis in Belize.
[27]
The Assemblies of God USA, as well as other Pentecostal and holiness churches, have historically
advocated abstinence from all alcohol, tobacco, and narcotics. Supporters of this view generally cite biblical
passages enjoining respect for one's body as well as forbidding intoxication.
[28]
Other Protestant churches have endorsed the legality of medical marijuana, including the Presbyterian
Church (USA), United Methodist Church, United Church of Christ, and the Episcopal Church.
[29]
In the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, there is general prohibition against intoxicating
substances. In August 1915, the LDS Church banned the use of cannabis by its members. In 2016, the
church's First Presidency urged members to oppose legalization of recreational cannabis use.
[30] 
The LDS
Church says it has "raised no objection to SB 89" (non-psychoactive medical marijuana in Utah).
[31][32]
During the Hindu festival of Holi and Maha Shivratri, people consume bhang which contains cannabis
flowers.
[33][34][35] 
According to one description, when the 
amrita 
(elixir of life) was produced from the
churning of the ocean by the devas and the asuras as described in the Samudra manthan, Shiva created
cannabis from his own body to purify the elixir (whence, for cannabis, the epithet angaja or "body-born").
Another account suggests that the cannabis plant sprang up when a drop of the elixir dropped on the
ground. Thus, cannabis is used by sages due to association with elixir and Shiva.
Orthodoxy
Protestantism
The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints
Hinduism

Bhang eaters from India c. 1790. Bhang is
an edible preparation of cannabis native to
the Indian subcontinent. It has been used
in food and drink as early as 1000 BCE by
Hindus in ancient India.
[36]
In Hinduism, wise drinking of bhang (which contains
cannabis), according to religious rites, is believed to cleanse
sins, unite one with Shiva and avoid the miseries of hell in the
future life. It is also believed to have medicinal benefits and is
used in Ayurvedic medicine.
[37] 
In contrast, foolish drinking of
bhang without rites is considered a sin.
[38]
The Quran does not mention cannabis. All major Sunni and
Shia scholars considered it by analogy (qiyas) to be similar to
khamr (intoxicants/alcoholic drink) and therefore deemed it
haraam 
(forbidden).
[39][40]
Those scholars who consider cannabis forbidden refer to a hadith by the prophet Mohammed regarding
alcoholic drinks, which states: "If much intoxicates, then even a little is haraam."
[41] 
However, early
Muslim jurists differentiated cannabis from alcohol, and despite restrictions on alcohol, cannabis use was
prevalent in the Islamic world until the 18th century.
[42] 
Today, cannabis is still consumed in many parts of
the Islamic world, even sometimes in a religious context particularly within the Sufi mystic movement.
[43]
In 1378 Soudoun Sheikouni, the Emir of the Joneima in Arabia, prohibited cannabis, considered one of the
world's first-attested cannabis bans.
[44]
The Sufi tradition attributes the discovery of cannabis to Jafar Sharazi (Sheikh Haydar), a Sufi leader in the
12th century.
[45] 
Other Sufis attribute its origin to the apocryphal Khidr ("Green Man").
[46]
Some modern Islamic leaders state that medical cannabis, but not recreational, is permissible in Islam. Imam
Mohammad Elahi in Dearborn Heights, Michigan (United States), declared: "Obviously, smoking
marijuana for fun is wrong... It should be permissible only if that is the only option in a medical condition
prescribed by medical experts."
[47] 
Non-intoxicating cannabis products such as CBD and hemp are
considered by many Islamic jurists to be permissible, especially when prescribed by a doctor as a treatment
for an illness. Products containing THC, however, are almost universally considered non-permissible, as
THC is the psychoactive component of cannabis.
[48]
The Nizari Shia military order which emerged after the fall of the Fatimid Caliphate is known in English as
the Assassins. This name derives from the Arabic word hashishin, meaning "hashish-smokers," after their
purported use of hashish in esoteric rituals, brainwashing, and to celebrate a successful kill. However,
historians dispute the extent to which these claims about the Assassins are true; some of these claims may be
rumours or embellishments put about by the Assassins' enemies, or spread by the Assassins themselves to
further their fearsome reputation. Other historians claim that these rituals were a form of self-defence to
grieve a fallen comrade or family member, for example, rather than just celebration to honour a kill.
Modern rabbis have debated whether cannabis is permissible under Jewish law for recreational or medicinal
purposes. Orthodox rabbi Moshe Feinstein stated in 1973 that cannabis was not permitted under Jewish

and is

Part of the Rastafari movement, elders of the 20th-century religious movement known as the Ethiopian Zion
Coptic Church, consider cannabis to be the "eucharist",

claiming it as an oral tradition from Ethiopia

In Sikhism, the First Sikh Guru, Guru Nanak, stated that using any mind altering substance (without

According to the

Rehat Maryada, "A Sikh must not take hemp (cannabis), opium, liquor, tobacco, in short any intoxicant.
His only routine intake should be food and water".
